commits.message:
Merge pull request #1228 from spatten/master

Fixing stale link in Leanpub documentation.

Merge pull request #1231 from github/update-maxcdn

Update maxcdn client gem

Merge pull request #1232 from github/remove-dead-services

Remove dead services
Remove Nodejitsu
Remov RationalJazzHub
Remove jquery Plugins

Merge pull request #1230 from github/vgrl-fix-415-response

add TeamCity Content-Type; 405 check; end tag
Update vendored gems

Update maxcdn gem version to latest

The latest version relaxes the constraint on signet, which is blocking
downstream dependencies for the hook delivery system.
add ending buildType tag
add missing pipe

add TeamCity Content-Type; 405 check; end tag

Added Content-Type; 405 status check; buildType closing tag
Fixing stale link in Leanpub documentation.

Merge pull request #1226 from github/remove-snapci

Remove Snap CI

Remove Snap CI

Signed-off-by: David Celis <me@davidcel.is>

Revert "Delete snapci.rb"

This reverts commit d7aabbcb83dfc837290f4bd549e0e213c75f12d7.
Delete snapci.rb

Merge pull request #1224 from github/strip-url

Strip URL

Strip url in http_method and http_get

Odd that http_get doesn't use http_method. Also odd that url could ever
be nil. How could one do an http request with a nil url.
Add failing tests for url that needs to be stripped

Merge pull request #1218 from lnussel/master

Avoid appending to url in a loop

Merge pull request #1215 from joesiewert/update-codeship

Update Codeship documentation

Merge pull request #1223 from github/nvw-active_collab_more_like_active_collNO

ActiveCollab: Slight Refactor to use `http_*` helpers.
rally: also use http helpers
active_collab: go through http_post

Merge pull request #1216 from brandonkelly/patch-1

Fixed broken link to "Integrations Directory"

Merge pull request #1222 from VladRassokhin/patch-1

Fix link in `teamcity` service documentation
Fix link in teamcity service documentation

Merge pull request #1221 from github/dbussink/remove-newer-ruby-syntax

Remove newer Ruby syntax

Remove newer Ruby syntax

This gem also needs to be backported to older GitHub Enterprise releases
who are not on a Ruby version that supports this syntax.

pull_requests.title: update and fix icescrum service
pull_requests.body:
- Fix bug with access_token
- update tests
- update doc

issue_comments.body: Thanks for this.  I wasn't serious when I called you out on Twitter :)  I'll let you know when this is integrated (should be this week) so you can test this out against Yammer.
I love the idea, but wouldn't you have to punch a hole in the firewall?  Do people normally have ports that speak the rabbitmq protocol open to the internet?
Wow, thanks for your patience on this.  Busy couple of weeks :)  This is my priority today.
Added!  Please check it out and confirm it works.  Thanks for your patience.
Added!  Please check it out and confirm it works.  Thanks for your patience.
Added!  Please check it out and confirm it works.  Thanks for your patience.
Added!  Please check it out and confirm it works.  Thanks for your patience.
Added!  Please check it out and confirm it works.  Thanks for your patience.
Added!  Please check it out and confirm it works.  Thanks for your patience.
Added!  Please check it out and confirm it works.  Thanks for your patience.
I don't know, they both use the same mechanism to send out pushes.  You should get a push with the last commit...  Do you have a test account I can play with?

Ah my bad, I had to [rename the files](https://github.com/github/github-services/commit/032ec45b0a2c4765ab7ab12aabdaf4abe00cf3f3) to fit our naming convention (ContinuityApp => continuity_app).  I just forgot to redeploy.  You should be good now.
Ah, the service hook used `api_token`, but the docs said `token`.  I fixed the service hook and redeployed.
It's fixed in e6e0c8d9d3af4f59da8462d26363b9926b203958.  Not sure why it was ever ssl in the first place.

Our web server uses EventMachine, so you don't have to worry about that.  I also just realized the service hook doesn't need to worry about starting or stopping the event loop.

I'm just going to cherry pick your 2 commits and push this.  I made a quick hack on the server and saw the hook requests go through without problems.

Already done: de6e882d8317ec3142074c4152f209b10696e27c  Thanks though :)

I hope we can work something out with your setup too -- though I'd prefer to stay compliant if possible.
Thanks for the update!  [Open a support issue](http://support.github.com) if you have problems with it.
Thanks for the update!  [Open a support issue](http://support.github.com) if you have problems with it.
Thanks for the update!  [Open a support issue](http://support.github.com) if you have problems with it.
Thanks for the update!  [Open a support issue](http://support.github.com) if you have problems with it.

commit_comments.body: Reverted.
lol
Ah, even better!  I guess we have an old version of the Basecamp API lib.  Thanks.
It's a requirement of the mapping of capital words to service names.  This text isn't visible to users though.
you're making me happy too

Yup, I added them for existing services after a big refactoring a few
months ago.  It's allowed me to use the merge button and speed up the
inclusion of service updates.
Yes.

review_comments.body:
It looks like you changed the default to FogBugz 7.  Is this intended?  

If `fb_repoid` is required for 7, why not just assume they're using FogBugz 7 if it's set?

About 21% of the configured hooks have no version set.  Of the 79% with configured versions, all but one are 7+.

I'll go ahead with the merge.  Thanks!
Push events have some pretty [elaborate helpers](https://github.com/github/github-services/blob/master/lib/events/push_helpers.rb#L19-35) for this stuff.

You can also check for `branch == "gh-pages"`.  Other repos on a user account can update subdirectories of the main pages repo.  So the `gh-pages` branch on `tater/foo` will update `tater.github.com/foo`.
Should that `.local` be `.com` ?
Always use https links please.
Is this hard-coded token right?
I'd prefer people not using instance variables in the service code.  But I'll fix this post-merge.
I'm confused... what is this code doing?  Does the `muc` object do something special after `#deliver_deferred` is used?  Doesn't look like this code is using `muc` at all after joining.
Lol, I understand that.  Do you by chance have experience with jabber libs in other languages?  I may just look for a good Python one or something.  http://sleekxmpp.com/ looks nice.

issue_comments.body: haha no worries.  I knew you were joking, or at least, I strongly hoped.

Sure. Here at Mozilla ours is accessible to the internet of course. I would imagine most people will hang something in the DMZ and have it proxy to an internal broker...who knows :-). I just know Mozilla is using github and will eventually need visibility into these changes, hence this service hook.
Ah, for the background: a related discussion is at http://support.github.com/discussions/post-receive-issues/140-service-hook-mantisbt-seems-to-post-to-wrong-url
Thanks!  When does this get deployed?  I don't see the new Install notes or 'username' field on the live site yet.

commit_comments.body: Interesting.  I need to take a look at our IRC server - with it's LDAP authentication turned on, it refuses to authenticate unless USER is first and PASS is second. I see this is not RFC compliant, so I propose we back out this change.

issue_comments.body: Tested - works correctly. Thanks very much for integrating it :)

Hi, thanks for integrating!

But, sounds like i doesn't work, i don't get any request to my webservices... is there a way to check logs?

Thanks for your help!
marco.

Hi!

Sorry for reopen this, but i'm still having issues: can't get any notification to my webservices from the hook, could be a ssl-related problem?

Thanks for your help,
marco.
It works on pushes, but the Test Hook button doesn't do anything, or at least we're not getting anything in our logs. What's wrong?
It works now. Thanks for all your help. :)

I originally wrote the MantisBT service hook, and worked with JonMarkGo to correct the problems it had, and this pull request should contain all the necessary fixes. Would appreciate this getting merged as soon as possible.

Thanks

commit_comments.body: This is still not right -- it's treating commit messages as a paste now and dropping the auto-link entirely

@netguru - I opened a ticket weeks ago, no response.  I heard they got bought out by Teambox, so maybe no one's really owning support at the moment.  Couldn't we just go with dashes and not wrap the URL in parenthesis?
@bensie - sorry about that :( I guess we should try to get talker to fix this

This totally breaks this service with my IRC server. The PASS command MUST be the first command sent to the server...

Cf. RFC 1459 (4.1.1 Password message): "The PASS command is used to set a 'connection password'.  The password can and must be set before any attempt to register the connection is made.  Currently this requires that clients send a PASS command before sending the NICK/USER combination and servers _must_ send a PASS command before any SERVER command...."
Basecamp requires SSL on all accounts now. I think that last ssl arg should always be true.
Did you mean to comment `Returns the last unread email` here at _Line 277_ ?
It's the vendored RDoc from the mail gem, you might try there.
Neato.
TeamCity is one word, not two, and is written as one word when lowercase, ex: http://jetbrains.com/teamcity/
Any reason that this couldn't be `response = speak(data, messages.join("\n"))` instead? That'd keep every line in multi-commit messages from being timestamped in Convore.
Thanks for merging and correcting my typos :)
Cool stuff.
:-1: I don't think I'm a fan of this change. I would rather go directly to the URL — campfire already shortens long URLs.
Badass! How long has `git.io` been around?
Why can we add only one address? What about adding CC or BCC? I can commit this if somebody need.
Agreed, in fact I think we specifically removed the shortening from this hook a while back.

review_comments.body:
```
url = "http://www.scrumdo.com/hooks/github/#{data["project_slug"]}"
```

commit_comments.body:
Sounds like it might make more sense to have it be optional

On Sep 29, 2011, at 6:18 PM, Tekkub
reply@reply.github.com
wrote:

> Agreed, in fact I think we specifically removed the shortening from this hook a while back.
> ## 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
> https://github.com/github/github-services/commit/c0fbacc2d6c6b3058924307e90d3e893fb0f4743#commitcomment-621537
That's interesting. But it's be cool if it could guess the repository's default branch and use it instead of hardcoding it to master.
Whoops, yeah we bumped the version to 11.1 instead of 11.0.2 and didn't run the tests after we bumped the version. Sorry about that man :)
Thanks! Didn't realize tests had been added to this project.
Is this live now?
Why was this disabled? I would like to be able to send to MUCs.

review_comments.body: I'm not 100% sure, but from what I was able to gather, this just joins the room so that deliver_deferred works. The deliver_deferred type is :groupchat, and the conference (actually a JID). It seems that you have to be joined to the room before the deliver_deferred works with MUCs.  My change was just to make it not try to maintain a connection, I assume the code before worked.
Also, Jabber::Simple is not the most idiomatic piece of Ruby out there :)

yes, I changed the default to 7+. I work at Fog Creek in support and we have very few customers still using pre-7 FogBugz. I think it would be better to remove the version field and just instruct people to put in the ixRepo if they're on 7+ but I didn't want to make big changes to this script since I'm not a Ruby guy and have no way to test it ;)
Is this necessary?  The SSL cert seems valid when I curl it.
That's what weeks of python development will do to you...
`https`
huh, I would have thought they'd just give us the branch name.
Well, this way you could watch for tags or whatever. Makes sense.
I'm embarrassed that I never looked. I'll fix this up to use them -- my bad!
I'm working it out
Done!
A new pull request fixing it is ready!
Yes, it should be there.  The per-user token will still be required from the user.

``` ruby
string :subdomain, :username, :branch 
password :password
```

This seems like it should work no?

Accept header should work as well here. Either `Accept: text/plain+diff` or using the `.diff` extension should work equally well. We don't only use `Accept` because there's no way to link to a content negotiated resource.
Sorry, I checked and it looks like the content negotiation was removed recently. The explicit `.diff` and `.patch` URLs are the only way to access this content.

Hmmm. I can't get it to work:

```
curl -H 'Accept: text/plain+diff' -D-  https://github.com/mojombo/grit/commit/06f63b43050935962f84fe54473a7c5de7977325 | grep Status
```

gives me:

```
Status: 406 Not Acceptable
```

On 4/24/12 2:55 PM, Lucas Madar wrote:

> > @@ -131,6 +131,24 @@ def commit_text(commit)
> > 
> > ```
> >  EOH
> > ```
> > -    if data['show_diff']
> > -      patch_resp = http_get commit['url'] + ".diff" # Why doesn't this use accept headers?
> 
> I am getting an error "Status 406" using the github e-mail service hook on my repositories with embedded diffs. Did something here get pushed that shouldn't have? Or is it unluckily unrelated?

I _might_ be related but I'm not sure. I originally tested with curl and
noticed that github didn't honor the "Accept" header and, in fact,
returned "406 Not Acceptable" (which is what you are getting) when I
passed in anything other than "text/html". But in the end I didn't set
the "Accept" header, so I don't understand why you would be seeing that.

There's a little bit of discussion of this section of the code in the
pull request here:
https://github.com/github/github-services/pull/275#r636575

For an example, check out this:

https://github.com/github/github-services/pull/275/commits

vs.

https://github.com/github/github-services/pull/275/commits.json

-David
I am getting an error "Status 406" using the github e-mail service hook on my repositories with embedded diffs. Did something here get pushed that shouldn't have? Or is it unluckily unrelated?

https://github.com/github/github-services/pull/275#r636575

- update tests
- update doc

issue_comments.body: Thanks for this.  I wasn't serious when I called you out on Twitter :)  I'll let you know when this is integrated (should be this week) so you can test this out against Yammer.
I love the idea, but wouldn't you have to punch a hole in the firewall?  Do people normally have ports that speak the rabbitmq protocol open to the internet?
Wow, thanks for your patience on this.  Busy couple of weeks :)  This is my priority today.
Added!  Please check it out and confirm it works.  Thanks for your patience.
Added!  Please check it out and confirm it works.  Thanks for your patience.
Added!  Please check it out and confirm it works.  Thanks for your patience.
Added!  Please check it out and confirm it works.  Thanks for your patience.
Added!  Please check it out and confirm it works.  Thanks for your patience.
Added!  Please check it out and confirm it works.  Thanks for your patience.
Added!  Please check it out and confirm it works.  Thanks for your patience.
I don't know, they both use the same mechanism to send out pushes.  You should get a push with the last commit...  Do you have a test account I can play with?

Ah my bad, I had to [rename the files](https://github.com/github/github-services/commit/032ec45b0a2c4765ab7ab12aabdaf4abe00cf3f3) to fit our naming convention (ContinuityApp => continuity_app).  I just forgot to redeploy.  You should be good now.
Ah, the service hook used `api_token`, but the docs said `token`.  I fixed the service hook and redeployed.
It's fixed in e6e0c8d9d3af4f59da8462d26363b9926b203958.  Not sure why it was ever ssl in the first place.

Our web server uses EventMachine, so you don't have to worry about that.  I also just realized the service hook doesn't need to worry about starting or stopping the event loop.

I'm just going to cherry pick your 2 commits and push this.  I made a quick hack on the server and saw the hook requests go through without problems.

Already done: de6e882d8317ec3142074c4152f209b10696e27c  Thanks though :)

I hope we can work something out with your setup too -- though I'd prefer to stay compliant if possible.
Thanks for the update!  [Open a support issue](http://support.github.com) if you have problems with it.
Thanks for the update!  [Open a support issue](http://support.github.com) if you have problems with it.

review_comments.body:
It looks like you changed the default to FogBugz 7.  Is this intended?  

If `fb_repoid` is required for 7, why not just assume they're using FogBugz 7 if it's set?

About 21% of the configured hooks have no version set.  Of the 79% with configured versions, all but one are 7+.

I'll go ahead with the merge.  Thanks!
Push events have some pretty [elaborate helpers](https://github.com/github/github-services/blob/master/lib/events/push_helpers.rb#L19-35) for this stuff.

You can also check for `branch == "gh-pages"`.  Other repos on a user account can update subdirectories of the main pages repo.  So the `gh-pages` branch on `tater/foo` will update `tater.github.com/foo`.
Should that `.local` be `.com` ?
Always use https links please.
Is this hard-coded token right?
I'd prefer people not using instance variables in the service code.  But I'll fix this post-merge.
I'm confused... what is this code doing?  Does the `muc` object do something special after `#deliver_deferred` is used?  Doesn't look like this code is using `muc` at all after joining.
Lol, I understand that.  Do you by chance have experience with jabber libs in other languages?  I may just look for a good Python one or something.  http://sleekxmpp.com/ looks nice.

issue_comments.body: haha no worries.  I knew you were joking, or at least, I strongly hoped.

Sure. Here at Mozilla ours is accessible to the internet of course. I would imagine most people will hang something in the DMZ and have it proxy to an internal broker...who knows :-). I just know Mozilla is using github and will eventually need visibility into these changes, hence this service hook.
Ah, for the background: a related discussion is at http://support.github.com/discussions/post-receive-issues/140-service-hook-mantisbt-seems-to-post-to-wrong-url
Thanks!  When does this get deployed?  I don't see the new Install notes or 'username' field on the live site yet.
Tested - works correctly. Thanks very much for integrating it :)

Hi, thanks for integrating!

But, sounds like i doesn't work, i don't get any request to my webservices... is there a way to check logs?

Thanks for your help!
marco.

Hi!

Sorry for reopen this, but i'm still having issues: can't get any notification to my webservices from the hook, could be a ssl-related problem?

Thanks for your help,
marco.
It works on pushes, but the Test Hook button doesn't do anything, or at least we're not getting anything in our logs. What's wrong?
It works now. Thanks for all your help. :)

I originally wrote the MantisBT service hook, and worked with JonMarkGo to correct the problems it had, and this pull request should contain all the necessary fixes. Would appreciate this getting merged as soon as possible.

Thanks

review_comments.body: yes, I changed the default to 7+. I work at Fog Creek in support and we have very few customers still using pre-7 FogBugz. I think it would be better to remove the version field and just instruct people to put in the ixRepo if they're on 7+ but I didn't want to make big changes to this script since I'm not a Ruby guy and have no way to test it ;)
Is this necessary?  The SSL cert seems valid when I curl it.

```
url = "http://www.scrumdo.com/hooks/github/#{data["project_slug"]}"
```
That's what weeks of python development will do to you...
`https`
huh, I would have thought they'd just give us the branch name.
Well, this way you could watch for tags or whatever. Makes sense.
I'm embarrassed that I never looked. I'll fix this up to use them -- my bad!
I'm working it out
Done!
A new pull request fixing it is ready!
Yes, it should be there.  The per-user token will still be required from the user.

``` ruby
string :subdomain, :username, :branch 
password :password
```

This seems like it should work no?

Accept header should work as well here. Either `Accept: text/plain+diff` or using the `.diff` extension should work equally well. We don't only use `Accept` because there's no way to link to a content negotiated resource.
Sorry, I checked and it looks like the content negotiation was removed recently. The explicit `.diff` and `.patch` URLs are the only way to access this content.

Hmmm. I can't get it to work:

```
curl -H 'Accept: text/plain+diff' -D-  https://github.com/mojombo/grit/commit/06f63b43050935962f84fe54473a7c5de7977325 | grep Status
```

gives me:

```
Status: 406 Not Acceptable
```

On 4/24/12 2:55 PM, Lucas Madar wrote:

> > @@ -131,6 +131,24 @@ def commit_text(commit)
> > 
> > ```
> >  EOH
> > ```
> > -    if data['show_diff']
> > -      patch_resp = http_get commit['url'] + ".diff" # Why doesn't this use accept headers?
> 
> I am getting an error "Status 406" using the github e-mail service hook on my repositories with embedded diffs. Did something here get pushed that shouldn't have? Or is it unluckily unrelated?

I _might_ be related but I'm not sure. I originally tested with curl and
noticed that github didn't honor the "Accept" header and, in fact,
returned "406 Not Acceptable" (which is what you are getting) when I
passed in anything other than "text/html". But in the end I didn't set
the "Accept" header, so I don't understand why you would be seeing that.

There's a little bit of discussion of this section of the code in the
pull request here:
https://github.com/github/github-services/pull/275#r636575

For an example, check out this:

https://github.com/github/github-services/pull/275/commits

vs.

https://github.com/github/github-services/pull/275/commits.json

-David
I am getting an error "Status 406" using the github e-mail service hook on my repositories with embedded diffs. Did something here get pushed that shouldn't have? Or is it unluckily unrelated?

I'm not 100% sure, but from what I was able to gather, this just joins the room so that deliver_deferred works. The deliver_deferred type is :groupchat, and the conference (actually a JID). It seems that you have to be joined to the room before the deliver_deferred works with MUCs.  My change was just to make it not try to maintain a connection, I assume the code before worked.
Also, Jabber::Simple is not the most idiomatic piece of Ruby out there :)

commit_comments.body: This is still not right -- it's treating commit messages as a paste now and dropping the auto-link entirely

@netguru - I opened a ticket weeks ago, no response.  I heard they got bought out by Teambox, so maybe no one's really owning support at the moment.  Couldn't we just go with dashes and not wrap the URL in parenthesis?
@bensie - sorry about that :( I guess we should try to get talker to fix this

This totally breaks this service with my IRC server. The PASS command MUST be the first command sent to the server...

Cf. RFC 1459 (4.1.1 Password message): "The PASS command is used to set a 'connection password'.  The password can and must be set before any attempt to register the connection is made.  Currently this requires that clients send a PASS command before sending the NICK/USER combination and servers _must_ send a PASS command before any SERVER command...."
Basecamp requires SSL on all accounts now. I think that last ssl arg should always be true.
Did you mean to comment `Returns the last unread email` here at _Line 277_ ?
It's the vendored RDoc from the mail gem, you might try there.
Neato.
TeamCity is one word, not two, and is written as one word when lowercase, ex: http://jetbrains.com/teamcity/
Any reason that this couldn't be `response = speak(data, messages.join("\n"))` instead? That'd keep every line in multi-commit messages from being timestamped in Convore.
Thanks for merging and correcting my typos :)
Cool stuff.
:-1: I don't think I'm a fan of this change. I would rather go directly to the URL — campfire already shortens long URLs.
Badass! How long has `git.io` been around?
Why can we add only one address? What about adding CC or BCC? I can commit this if somebody need.
Agreed, in fact I think we specifically removed the shortening from this hook a while back.
